name: Vitamin D: A Structured Bayesian Knowledge Collection
description: A collection of three distinct knowledge claims regarding Vitamin D supplementation, each analyzed using the Legis Ledger Structured Bayesian Pluralism framework. This index provides a high-level overview of confidence and evidence maturity across related scientific topics.

@graph.claim: Vitamin D supplementation reduces risk of non-vertebral fractures and improves bone mineral density (BMD) in deficient adults.
@graph.summary: Decades of canonical evidence (Cochrane) strongly support this claim, especially when combined with calcium and targeting deficient populations. BF (9.5) is Strong evidence.

@graph.claim: Vitamin D supplementation to prevent dementia is uncertain - observational associations exist but RCT evidence is insufficient.
@graph.summary: Observational data is compelling, but limited RCTs show mixed or null results. This claim sits at epistemic equipoise (50% confidence), pending definitive long-term trial data. BF (1.0) is Anecdotal.

@graph.claim: Vitamin D reduces the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) and all-cause cardiovascular mortality.
@graph.summary: Large, well-powered RCTs (VITAL) have conclusively demonstrated no benefit in the general population. The evidence favors the null hypothesis. BF against the claim (2.25) is Weak/Anecdotal.

provenanceAndLimitations.notSubmittedByAuthority: NOT submitted by FDA or NIH
potentialBiases: Analysis may be biased toward published consensus of null effect in recent large trials.
howToVerify: Check Cochrane Reviews, NIH, and major RCT publications (e.g., VITAL).
